data.title: 100 Cool Celtic Last Names: Unique and Legendary
data.meta_description: Our compelling guide makes it easy to know how Celtic last names evolved over the centuries and where they are in the world today.
data.text:
Much of the culture of the Emerald Isle (and the United Kingdom as a whole) is influenced by Celtic last names. How best can you distinguish between the many forms of Celtic surnames in existence?

Here you‚Äôll learn much about Celtic last names, from those beginning with ‚ÄúO‚Äù and ‚ÄúMc‚Äù to less common Viking-influenced names. Get ready for all the famous namesakes, pronunciations, and variations that make Celtic last names rock!

100 Popular Celtic Surnames

These Celtic last names are loaded with magic rooted in bountiful history that continues to fascinate.

Ahearn

Ahearn comes from the Irish ‚Äú√ì‚ÄôEachthigheirn,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúdescendent of Eachthighearna.‚Äù It‚Äôs made of the Celtic ‚Äúeach,‚Äù meaning ‚Äústeed,‚Äù and ‚Äúthighearna,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúlord.‚Äù

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Horse lord

Pronunciation: Ah-HHERN

Variations: Ahearne

Namesakes: Theresa Ahearn, an Irish Teachta D√°la representative from 1989 to 2000. Joe Ahearne, an Irish TV writer best known for Doctor Who.

Popularity: Ahearn is rare worldwide and mostly used in the U.S.

Barry

Barry represents the Anglo form of the Irish √ì‚ÄôBeargha, meaning ‚Äúdescendant of Beargh‚Äù or ‚Äúspear-like.‚Äù It‚Äôs also associated with the Irish √ì B√°ire, denoting someone from the town ‚Äúof Barry.‚Äù

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Plunderer

Pronunciation: BEAHR-iy

Variations: Barey, Barrey, Barrie

Namesakes: Max Barry, an Australian author known for Syrup (1999). Todd Barry, an American comedian appearing on Aqua Teen Hunger Force.

Popularity: Barry ranked 460th worldwide, is mainly used in Guinea, and ranked 49th in Ireland in 2014.

Blevins

Belvins uses the Welsh root ‚Äúblaidd,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúwolf.‚Äù It uses an ‚Äú-ins‚Äù suffix to reduce the big bad wolf to a cut, fuzzy wolf cub.

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Wolf cub

Pronunciation: BLEH-vihns

Variations: Blevin

Namesakes: Bret Blevins, an American comics artist of New Mutants for Marvel Comics. Dean Blevins, an American sportscaster for KWTV CBS in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma.

Popularity: Blevins is rare worldwide and primarily used in the U.S., where it ranked 893rd in 2014.

Brogan

Like other Irish surnames, Brogan is an Anglo variation of a Celtic name. It derives from √ì‚ÄôBr√≥g√°in, meaning ‚Äúson of Brogan,‚Äù from ‚Äúbr√≥g,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúshoe.‚Äù

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Small shoe

Pronunciation: BROW-Gahn

Variations: O‚ÄôBrogan

Namesakes: John Brogan, a Scottish footballer for Glasgow Perthshire. Nicola Brogan, a Northern Irish member of the Legislative Assembly since 2020.

Popularity: Brogan is rare worldwide, mostly used in the U.S., and ranked 518th in Ireland in 2014.

Buckley

Buckley is based on the Celtic √ì‚ÄôBuachalla, from ‚Äúbuachaill,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúherdsman.‚Äù It transformed into √ì‚ÄôBoughelly, Buhilly, and, finally, Buckley.

Origin: Celtic, English

Meaning: Bleak hill

Pronunciation: BUHK-Liy

Variations: Buckleah, Bucklee

Namesakes: Jeffrey Buckley, an American musician best known for his cover of Leonard Cohen‚Äôs ‚ÄúHallelujah.‚Äù William F. Buckley Jr., an American political commentator who founded National Review in 1955.

Popularity: Buckley is uncommon worldwide, primarily used in the U.S., and ranked 53rd in Ireland in 2014.

Byrne

Byrne first appeared as the Gaelic O‚ÄôBroin, meaning ‚Äúdescendant of Bran.‚Äù Bran was the king of Leinster who influenced this ‚Äúraven‚Äù like name to the modern world.

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Ravens

Pronunciation: BAHRN

Variations: O‚ÄôByrne, Byrnes

Namesakes: David Byrne, a Scottish-American musician, and member of Talking Heads. Mary Byrne, the Mayor of Galway from 1984 to 1985.

Popularity: Byrne is uncommon worldwide and mainly used in Ireland, ranking 3rd in 2014.

Cadwallader

Like other Celtic last names, Cadwallader is patronymic, meaning ‚Äúthe son of Cadwaladyr.‚Äù It‚Äôs based on the Welsh Cadwaladyr, composed of ‚Äúcad,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúbattle,‚Äù and ‚Äúgwaladr,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúleader.‚Äù

Origin: Celtic, Welsh

Meaning: Battle leader

Pronunciation: Cad-WAAL-ah-Dehr

Variations: Cadwaladr

Namesakes: Douglass Cadwallader, an American golfer, and bronze medalist at the 1904 Summer Olympics. Gavin Cadwallader, an English footballer for Shrewsbury Town.

Popularity: Cadwallader is very rare worldwide, mostly used in the U.S., and ranked 1,284th in Wales in 2014.

Campbell

Campbell is made up of the Celtic ‚Äúcam,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúcrooked,‚Äù and ‚Äúbeul,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúmouth.‚Äù The Campbell clan was famous for its chief Colin Mor Campbell, known as Colin The Great.

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Crooked mouth

Pronunciation: KAEM-Bahl

Variations: Cambell, Campbel

Namesakes: Bruce Campbell, an American actor known for the Evil Dead horror films. Thomas Campbell, a Scottish poet, and co-founder of the Literary Association of the Friends of Poland.

Popularity: Campbell ranked 657th worldwide, is mainly used in the U.S., and ranked #1 in Northern Ireland in 2014.

Carey

Carey comes from the Celtic O‚ÄôCiardha, meaning ‚Äúdescendant of Ciardh.‚Äù It was first a given name based on ‚Äúciar,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúblack,‚Äù and also works as an offbeat boy‚Äôs name.

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Dark

Pronunciation: KEHR-iy

Variations: Cary, Carrey

Namesakes: Jack Carey, an American jazz musician and leader of the Crescent City Orchestra. Peter Carey, an Australian novelist who, won the Booker Prize twice.

Popularity: Carey is uncommon worldwide, primarily used in the U.S., and ranked 111th in Ireland in 2014.

Carmody

Carmody derives from the Gaelic √ì‚ÄôCearmada, meaning ‚Äúdescendant of Cearmad.‚Äù It‚Äôs also associated with ‚Äúcearmadach,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúindustrious,‚Äù and occurs most in Counties Clare and Limerick.

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Industrious

Pronunciation: KAAR-mah-Diy

Namesakes: Robert Carmody, an American boxer and bronze medalist at the 1964 Summer Olympics. Donald Carmody, an American-Canadian film producer and winner of an Academy Award in 2002 for Chicago.

Popularity: Carmody is rare worldwide, primarily used in the U.S., and ranked 580th in Ireland in 2014.

Casey

Casey is based on the Irish O‚ÄôCathasaigh, meaning ‚Äúvigilant.‚Äù It was used by multiple rulers in Irish history, like O‚ÄôCasey and MacCasey.

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Watchful

Pronunciation: KEY-Siy

Variations: Casie, Cacey

Namesakes: Kenneth Casey, an American musician, and member of the Dropkick Murphys. William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence from 1981 to 1987.

Popularity: Casey is uncommon worldwide, mainly used in the U.S., and ranked 55th in Ireland in 2014.

Cavanagh

Cavanaugh is an Anglicized version of Caomhanach, meaning ‚Äúfollower of St. Caomhan.‚Äù It was first used by Domhnall, the son of a 12th-century Irish king.

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Follower of Kevin

Pronunciation: KAEV-ah-Nao

Variations: Kavanagh, Kavanaugh

Namesakes: Megan Cavanagh, an American actress known for A League of Their Own. Se√°n Cavanagh, an Irish Gaelic footballer for Tyrone.

Popularity: Cavanaugh is rare worldwide, primarily used in the U.S., and ranked 833rd in Ireland in 2014.

Cleary

Cleary is an Anglo form of the Irish √ì‚ÄôCl√©irigh, meaning ‚Äúdescendant of Cl√©ireach.‚Äù It was a surname given to a ‚Äúcleric,‚Äù while McCleary was used for the ‚Äúson of the cleric.‚Äù

Origin: Celtic

Meaning: Cleric

Pronunciation: KLIH-Riy

Variations: Clearey, Clearie

Namesakes: Beverly Cleary, an American children‚Äôs book writer known for the Ramona Quimby character. Bill Cleary, an American ice hockey player and gold medalist at the 1980 Winter Olympics.

Popularity: Cleary is rare worldwide, primarily used in the U.S., and ranked 21st in Ireland in 2014.

Collins

Collins is the English equivalent of the Irish Cullane, dating back to √ì‚ÄôCoile√°in. Though some believe it to mean ‚Äúholly,‚Äù others see the root of Collins as a word meaning ‚Äúyoung dog.‚Äù

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Holly

Pronunciation: KAAH-Lihnz

Variations: Colin, Collin

Namesakes: Michael Collins, an Irish revolutionary and Director of Intelligence of the Irish Republican Army (IRA). Phil Collins, an English musician, and member of Genesis.

Popularity: Collins ranked 820th worldwide, is primarily used in the U.S., and ranked 26th in Ireland in 2014.

Corcoran

Corcoran derives from √ì‚ÄôCorcr√°in, meaning ‚Äúdescendant of Corcr√°n.‚Äù It‚Äôs based on the Irish ‚Äúcorcair,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúpurple.‚Äù Corcoran was once given to someone with a ‚Äúred (or ruddy) complexion.‚Äù

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Red complexion

Pronunciation: KAOR-ker-Ahn

Variations: Cochran

Namesakes: Barbara Corcoran, an American businesswoman who founded The Corcoran Group. Fred J. Corcoran, a golf tournament director and one of the first non-players inducted into the World Golf Hall of Fame in 1975.

Popularity: Corcoran is rare worldwide, mostly used in the U.S., and ranked 103rd in Ireland in 2014.

Cosgrove

Cosgrove is one of many geographically-based Celtic surnames, meaning ‚Äúof Cosgrove,‚Äù in Northamptonshire, England. Many towns and villages ending in ‚Äú-grove‚Äù denote a ‚Äúthicket‚Äù or a ‚Äúsmall wood.‚Äù

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Victorious champion

Pronunciation: KAAS-Grohv

Variations: Cosgrave

Namesakes: Stephen E. Cosgrove, a children‚Äôs author known for the Serendipity series of books. Michael Cosgrove, an American baseball player with the Houston Astros.

Popularity: Cosgrove is rare worldwide, mainly used in the U.S., and ranked 418th in Ireland in 2014.

Cotter

Cotter comes from the Celtic MacOitir, a Norse reference to Ottar, an 8th-century Viking chieftain. Its English origins lead to an occupational use for a ‚Äúpeasant farmer.‚Äù

Origin: Celtic, English

Meaning: Cottager

Pronunciation: COTT-ehr

Variations: McCotter, Cottar

Namesakes: Imogen Cotter, an Irish racing cyclist for UCI Women‚Äôs Continental Team Ciclotel. Wayne Cotter, an American comedian who hosted Comic Strip Live from 1991 to 1994.

Popularity: Cotter is rare worldwide, primarily used in the U.S., and ranked 224th in Ireland in 2014.

Coughlan

Coughlan comes from the Irish O‚ÄôCochlain, taken from ‚Äúcochal,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúcloak‚Äù or ‚Äúhood.‚Äù It‚Äôs famous for Dealbha, the brother of King Blad of Munster, in Ireland.

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Son of the one with the cloak

Pronunciation: KOH-Luhn

Variations: Coghlan, Coughlin

Namesakes: Nicola Coughlan, an Irish actress known for the sitcom Derry Girls (2018 to 2022). Richard Coughlan, an English musician and drummer for the band Caravan.

Popularity: Coughlan is rare worldwide and mainly used in Ireland, where it ranked 133rd in 2014.

Cunningham

Cunningham consists of the Gaelic ‚Äúcuinneag,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúmilk pail,‚Äù and ‚Äúham,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúvillage.‚Äù It also means ‚Äúdescendant of Cuinneag√°n‚Äù based on ‚Äúconn,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúchief.‚Äù

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Village of the milk pail

Pronunciation: KAHN-ing-Haem

Variations: Cuningham, Cunnyngham

Namesakes: Michael Cunningham, an American novelist, and winner of the 1998 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction. Stacey Cunningham, the 67th president of the New York Stock Exchange from 2018 to 2022.

Popularity: Cunningham is uncommon worldwide, mostly used in the U.S., and ranked 53rd in Northern Ireland in 2014.

Daley

Daley is taken from the Celtic √ì‚ÄôD√°laigh, which uses the root ‚Äúd√°l,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúgathering.‚Äù It refers to any ‚Äúmeeting‚Äù or ‚Äúassembly.‚Äù One of the first Celtic figures using Daly was Eanna Ceannselach, the 5th-century king of Leinster.

Origin: Celtic, Welsh

Meaning: Meeting

Pronunciation: DEY-Liy

Variations: Daily, Daly

Namesakes: Michael Daley, the Attorney-General of New South Wales since 2023. Brian Daley, an American science fiction novelist known for adapting Star Wars radio dramas.

Popularity: Daley is rare worldwide, mainly used in the U.S., and ranked 837th in Wales in 2014.

Delaney

Delaney was originally the Gaelic √ì‚ÄôDubhshl√°ine and is made up of ‚Äúdubh,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúblack,‚Äù and ‚Äúsl√°ine,‚Äù meaning ‚ÄúRiver Sl√°ine.‚Äù Delaney also means ‚Äúfrom the alder grove.‚Äù

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Dark challenger

Pronunciation: Deh-LEY-niy

Variations: Delany, Dulaney

Namesakes: Edward Delaney, an Irish sculptor known for the 1967 statue of Wolfe Tone. Rob Delaney, an American comedian and co-writer of the series Catastrophe.

Popularity: Delaney is rare worldwide, primarily used in the U.S., and ranked 79th in Ireland in 2014.

Devlin

Devlin derives from the Gaelic O‚ÄôDobhailen, meaning ‚Äúdescendant of Dobhalen,‚Äù plus ‚Äúraging valor.‚Äù It‚Äôs made up of the Irish ‚Äúdobh,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúboisterous,‚Äù ‚Äúal,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúvalor,‚Äù and the suffix ‚Äú-en.‚Äù

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Fierce courage

Pronunciation: DEHV-Lihn

Variations: Develin

Namesakes: Janet Devlin, a Northern Irish singer-songwriter who competed in The X Factor in 2011. Ben Devlin, a British TV executive producer for the BBC.

Popularity: Devlin is rare worldwide, mostly used in the U.S., and ranked 49th in Northern Ireland in 2014.

Dillon

Dillon is based on the Irish D√≠olmhain, meaning ‚Äúfaithful‚Äù and ‚Äútrue.‚Äù It‚Äôs been associated with Norman surnames since the 12th century and means ‚Äúlike a lion‚Äù and ‚Äúloyalty.‚Äù

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Like a lion

Pronunciation: DIHL-ahn

Variations: Dylan, Dylon

Namesakes: Matt Dillon, an American actor known for The Outsiders (1983). Richard C. Dillon, the eighth governor of New Mexico from 1927 to 1931.

Popularity: Dillon is rare worldwide, mainly used in the U.S., and ranked 137th in Ireland in 2014.

Doherty

Doherty is one of the best-known Celtic last names, taken from the Gaelic O‚ÄôDochartaigh. It first referred to a ‚Äúdescendant of Dochartach,‚Äù also meaning ‚Äúunlucky‚Äù or ‚Äúhurtful.‚Äù

Origin: Celtic, Scottish

Meaning: Unlucky

Pronunciation: DOW-er-Tiy

Variations: O‚ÄôDoherty, Dougharty

Namesakes: Kathleen A. Doherty, the U.S. Ambassador to Cyprus from 2015 to 2019. Paddy Doherty, a Gaelic footballer and the captain for Down.

Popularity: Doherty is rare worldwide, primarily used in the U.S., and ranked 17th in Northern Ireland in 2014.

Donnelly

Donnelly derives from the Gaelic Donnghalach, meaning ‚Äúdark brave one.‚Äù It was a surname for a ‚Äúdescendant of Donnghal,‚Äù which became Donnelly for today‚Äôs courageous ones.

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Dark valor

Pronunciation: DAAN-eh-Liy

Variations: Donally, Donelly

Namesakes: Fin Donnelly, a Canadian member of the Legislative Assembly of British Columbia since 2020. Scott Donnelly, an English footballer for Hayes & Yeading United.

Donohue

Donohue comes from the Gaelic √ì‚ÄôDonnchadha, meaning ‚Äúdescendant of Donnchadh.‚Äù Donohue was a given name in the 9th century but became a common surname during the 10th-century.

Origin: Celtic

Meaning: Brown-haired

Pronunciation: DAA-nah-HHyuw

Variations: Donaghue, Donahugh

Namesakes: Phil Donahue, an American host of The Phil Donahue Show (1967 to 1996). Elinor Donahue, an American actress known for the sitcom Father Knows Best.

Popularity: Donohue is rare worldwide, mostly used in the U.S., and ranked 532nd in Ireland in 2014.

Doyle

Doyle once referred to a place name ‚Äúde Oilgi,‚Äù in Normandy, France. It stems from the Irish √ì Dubhghaill, meaning ‚Äúdescendant of Dubhghall,‚Äù and became one of the coolest Irish surnames today.

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Dark stranger

Pronunciation: DOYL

Variations: Doyal, Doyel

Namesakes: Arthur Conan Doyle, a British writer who created Sherlock Holmes in 1887. Brian Doyle-Murray, an American actor known for Ghostbusters II (1989).

Popularity: Doyle is uncommon worldwide, primarily used in the U.S., and ranked 9th in Ireland in 2014.

Duffy

Duffy is the Anglo variation of the Irish Dubhthach, made up of ‚Äúdubh,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúdark,‚Äù and the suffix ‚Äú-thach.‚Äù It‚Äôs best associated with the 5th-century king Laeghaire‚Äôs poet Dubhthach.

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Dark complexion

Pronunciation: DAHF-iy

Variations: Duffey, O‚ÄôDuffy

Namesakes: Keith Duffy, an Irish singer, and member of the Irish boy band Boyzone. Carol Ann Duffy, a Scottish poet and Poet Laureate in 2009.

Popularity: Duffy is uncommon worldwide, mostly used in the U.S., and ranked 36th in Ireland in 2014.

Dunne

Dunne is associated with the Irish √ì‚ÄôDuinn, meaning ‚Äúbrown.‚Äù It also means ‚Äúat the dun‚Äù (or ‚Äúat the hill‚Äù) in Middle English.

Origin: Celtic

Meaning: Dark

Pronunciation: DUN

Variations: Dunn, Donne

Namesakes: Griffin Dunne, an American actor known for An American Werewolf in London (1981). Ross Dunne, an Australian rules footballer for the Collingwood Football Club.

Popularity: Dunne is rare worldwide and mainly used in Ireland, ranking 14th in 2014.

Farrell means ‚Äúchampion,‚Äù as based on the Irish Ferghal, made up of ‚Äúfer,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúman,‚Äù and ‚Äúgab,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúvalor.‚Äù It also means ‚Äúdescendant of Fearghal‚Äù and ‚Äúman of valor,‚Äù to boot.

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Champion

Pronunciation: FAH-Rehl

Variations: Farell, Farrel, Farryll

Namesakes: Colin Farrell, an Irish actor named Ireland‚Äôs fifth-greatest film actor by Time Magazine in 2020. Craig Farrell, an English footballer for Carlisle United.

Ferguson

Ferguson represents the English spelling for the Scottish-Gaelic Macfhearghus. It was a patronymic surname for the ‚Äúson of Fergus‚Äù or ‚Äúson of the angry (one).‚Äù

Variations: Fergusson

Namesakes: Craig Ferguson, a Scottish-American host of The Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson (2005 to 2014). Patricia Ferguson, a member of the Scottish Parliament from 2011 to 2016.

Finn

Finn originally appeared as the Irish √ì Finn, meaning ‚Äúdescendant of Fionn.‚Äù It means ‚Äúfair-haired‚Äù when taken from the Old Norse Finnr, making Finn one of the Celtic family names with Viking origins.

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: White-haired

Pronunciation: FIHN

Variations: Finn, Fynn

Namesakes: Mali Finn, an American casting director known for casting Leonardo DiCaprio and Russell Crowe. Chris Finn, a Canadian comedian who won the 2001 Canadian Comedy Award.

Fitzpatrick

Fitzpatrick was originally the Gaelic Mac Giolla Ph√°draig, meaning ‚Äúson of the Devotee of (St.) Patrick.‚Äù This very badass clan ruled one of the oldest Irish kingdoms, including Laois and Kilkenny.

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Son of Patrick

Pronunciation: Fihts-PAEH-triyk

Fitzsimmons

Fitzsimmons is one of many Celtic surnames with Norman origins. It also appeared as Sigmundsson, meaning ‚Äúson of Sigmund,‚Äù and was once Mac S√≠om√≥in.

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Son of Sigmund

Pronunciation: Fiht-SIH-Mahnz

Variations: Fitzsimons, Fytzsimmons

Namesakes: Stuart Fitzsimmons, a British alpine skier who competed at the 1976 Winter Olympics. Greg Fitzsimmons, an American host of The Greg Fitzsimmons Show.

Flanagan

Flanagan derives from the Gaelic √ì‚ÄôFlannag√°in, composed of ‚Äúflann,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúred or ruddy complexion.‚Äù It also means ‚Äúdescendant of Flannag√°n‚Äù for those with the motto ‚ÄúI have fought and conquered.‚Äù

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Ruddy

Pronunciation: FLAH-naa-Gan

Variations: Flannagan

Namesakes: Edward J. Flanagan, an Irish-American Catholic priest who founded Boys Town. Fionnula Flanagan, an Irish actress known for The Others (2001).

Flynn

Flynn is a simplified version of the Irish √ì‚ÄôFloinn, meaning ‚Äúdescendant of Flann.‚Äù It was used for someone with a particularly ‚Äúreddish or ruddy complexion.‚Äù

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Red

Pronunciation: FLIHN

Variations: Flinn, Flyn, Flyne

Namesakes: Errol Flynn, an Australian-American actor known for The Adventures of Robin Hood (1938). P√°draig Flynn, the Irish European Commissioner for Social Affairs from 1993 to 1999.

Popularity: Flynn is uncommon worldwide, primarily used in the U.S., and ranked 25th in Ireland in 2014.

Foley

The Foley surname originates in the Irish counties of Cork, Kerry, and Waterford. It‚Äôs based on the Gaelic √ì‚ÄôFoghladha, meaning ‚Äúpirate‚Äù or ‚Äúmarauder,‚Äù for a uniquely adventurous spirit.

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Pirate

Pronunciation: FOW-liy

Variations: Foaley, Fowley

Namesakes: Dave Foley, a Canadian actor and co-founder of The Kids in the Hall comedy group. James Foley, an American film director known for Glengarry Glen Ross (1992).

Friel

Friel comes from the Gaelic O‚ÄôFirgil, meaning ‚Äúman of valor.‚Äù It first appeared as the Gaelic O‚ÄôFirghil, made up of ‚Äúfear,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúman,‚Äù and ‚Äúgal,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúvalor.‚Äù

Origin: Celtic

Meaning: Man of valor

Pronunciation: FREEL

Variations: O‚ÄôFriel

Namesakes: Anna Friel, an English actress appearing on ABC‚Äôs Pushing Daisies (2007 to 2009). Brian Friel, an Irish dramatist who co-founded the Field Day Theatre Company in 1980.

Popularity: Friel is rare worldwide, mainly used in the U.S., and ranked 437th in Northern Ireland in 2014.

Fylan

Fylan was first Faolan, based on the Gaelic ‚Äúfael,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúlittle wolf.‚Äù It‚Äôs also related to O‚ÄôFaolain and O‚ÄôFialain, which became the Anglicized Phelan today.

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Little wolf

Pronunciation: FAEY-lan

Variations: O‚ÄôFaolain

Popularity: Fylan is extremely rare worldwide, with 120 known occurrences in 2014, primarily in England.

Gallagher

Gallagher is taken from the Gaelic ‚Äúgallchobhair,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúforeign help.‚Äù It also means ‚Äúeager help‚Äù and originated with Irish royalty in the 8th-century.

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Foreign help

Pronunciation: GAHL-ah-Gher

Variations: O‚ÄôGallagher, Gallager

Popularity: Gallagher is uncommon worldwide, primarily used in the U.S., and ranked 23rd in Ireland in 2014.

Guinness

Guinness derives from the Gaelic Mag Aonghuis, meaning ‚Äúson of Angus.‚Äù It‚Äôs most typical as the famously dark Irish stout beer created by Arthur Guinness in the late 18th century.

Meaning: Son of Angus

Hannigan

Hannigan has Norman origins derived from Johann, meaning ‚Äúson of Hann.‚Äù It‚Äôs associated with the Gaelic √ì‚ÄôAnnag√°in, meaning ‚Äúdescendant of Annag√°n,‚Äù so all names are covered here.

Origin: Celtic, Irish

Meaning: Son of Hann

Pronunciation: HAA-nah-Gahn

Variations: O‚ÄôHannigan
